content_theme.scene_description:
Primary Scene Analysis:
Three figures occupy a single unified scene. A central woman, facing three-quarters right, wears a long ultramarine-blue robe with white coif and black shoes. She bears a wooden yoke across her shoulders supporting two wicker baskets filled with green herbs. To her left, a man in a purple tunic, black hat, hose, and pointed black shoes stands on a slightly lower plane, holding handfuls of herbs. To her right, a man in a red tunic emerges from a stone archway, carrying a similar yoke and basket. All figures stand on a wooden plank platform that slopes slightly downward to the left.
Spatial Organization:
Foreground activity is framed by a tree at upper left and a building arch at upper right; the background is a gently rolling hillscape dotted with stylized herb plants.
Costume and Equipment Details:
The woman’s robe is trimmed with a narrow white band at the hem; the men’s tunics have visible seam lines and simple belts. Baskets are rendered with distinct wicker weave. The wooden yoke shows carved end caps.
Secondary Elements:
The scene is enclosed in a deep red rectangular frame. The stone building features a round-arched opening with dotted voussoirs. A stylized tree with dark foliage provides counterbalance. The background ground plane tilts upward to display the garden bed.
Symbolic Components:
Baskets of green herbs illustrate the text’s subject (“Porri”). The yoke signifies labor. The arch may allude to monastic enclosure.
Compositional Focus:
The central woman draws the viewer’s eye by placement and brighter color. Supporting figures direct attention inward through gesture.
Visual-Textual Relationships:
The miniature directly illustrates the heading “Porri” and the text describing the nature and uses of leeks. The ornamental initial N connects visually to the image’s palette. Marginal foliate sprigs echo the herbs in the basket. The red rubric signals the start of the herbal entry, linking image and text.

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Monastic physicians and university-trained medical practitioners

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This page likely originates from a mid-15th-century French herbal or medical compendium produced in a university or monastic workshop, reflecting the period’s fusion of practical botany and graphic instruction. The clear depiction of herb gathering, labeled “Porri,” corresponds to the medieval emphasis on materia medica laid out in Circa Instans–type manuscripts. The International Gothic style, with its bright pigments, refined gold tooling, and soft white highlights, indicates a high-status commission for an educated audience. The use of ultramarine, likely imported, and precisely executed underdrawings suggest collaboration within a specialized atelier employing multiple hands. Iconographically, the scene emphasizes labor and nature, devoid of religious symbolism, underlining the secular, utilitarian purpose of the work. The architectural arch and tree serve compositional and didactic functions, framing the activity and situating it in an idealized hortus conclusus. Comparatively, the palette and figure types recall the Tacuinum Sanitatis codices, while the professional book hand and rubrication align with Parisian medical manuscripts of the period. This page exemplifies the confluence of art and science in late medieval Europe, illustrating how illumination enhanced the accessibility of herbal knowledge for both monastic and academic communities.
